Award.AwardTitle: Transitioning Funded Research Outcomes to Practice: Barriers, Opportunities, and Challenges

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The United States has taken a leadership role in initiating and funding research in Cyber security over several decades. Although the research has yielded significant advances in both understanding the underlying issues associated with cyber security and describing increasingly effective measures for securing information systems, only a small fraction of this insight has been transferred to fielded systems, government or commercial. Deficiency in the area of transferring technology to practice is a pressing issue in the U.S. today.

This Cyber Security Transition to Practice workshop seeks to identify means by which NSF can facilitate technology transfer at multiple points in the process: for the researcher, institution, funding agency, and investor.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The University of South Alabama organized and conducted a two day workshop of SMEs and TTP experts from academia, industry, and government. The jointly sponsored NSF/DHS Cyber Security Transition to Practice workshop was held on February 25-26 in the SRI Innovation Center in Menlo Park, California. The workshop was attended by 29 participants from industry (14), venture (4), government (4), and academia (7). Many of the industry participants are previous NSF awardees who transferred their sponsored research into practice.
Participants addressed questions such as what is and is not happening that prevents tech transfer from occurring, observations on the state of TTP efforts, and what changes in the existing TTP process might improve the odds of success. Some of the key findings follow:
1. NSF must establish clear TTP goals and objectives.
2. Recognize and embrace the many TTP types/modes.
3. Consider developing an “off ramp” model for TTP.
4. NSF should create a TTP Ecosystem/infrastructure for its funded projects.
5. NSF’s TTP plan should recognize, all stakeholders.
6. Access to a PI with TTP experience is vital to the success of a TTP project
7. Offer strong incentives to PIs with previous TTP experience
8. Build a PI TTP Pipeline for motivated young PIs to gain TTP experience
9. PIs need access to significant datasets to be able to generate TTP-worthy products.
10. PI training and familiarization is needed to create a culture of TTP among NSF funded projects
11. Consider differences between NSF and TTP pipelines
12. Some topics are naturally better suited to TTP than others and often depend on market demands.
13. TTP  involves assuming risk
14. Integrating TTP into research program solicitations greatly complicates peer review
15. Business schools (and other academic departments) can often contribute to successful TTP for Cybersecurity projects 
NSF has used outcomes from this workshop to improve TTP for cybersecurity, e.g. by adjusting elements in solicitations in response information gathered in the workshop and also to expand and enrich strategic planning for further NSF-funded cybersecurity TTP successes, including conducting a second TTP workshop to advance results from this event.

Some of the key findings follow: 1. NSF must establish clear TTP goals and objectives. 2. Recognize and embrace the many TTP types/modes. 3. Consider developing an "off ramp" model for TTP. 4. NSF should create a TTP Ecosystem/infrastructure for its funded projects. 5. NSF?s TTP plan should recognize, all stakeholders. 6. Access to a PI with TTP experience is vital to the success of a TTP project 7. Offer strong incentives to PIs with previous TTP experience 8. Build a PI TTP Pipeline for motivated young PIs to gain TTP experience 9. PIs need access to significant datasets to be able to generate TTP-worthy products. 10. Integrating TTP into research program solicitations greatly complicates peer review 15. Business schools (and other academic departments) can often contribute to successful TTP for Cybersecurity projects NSF has used outcomes from this workshop to improve TTP for cybersecurity, e.g. by adjusting elements in solicitations in response information gathered in the workshop and also to expand and enrich strategic planning for further NSF-funded cybersecurity TTP successes, including conducting a second TTP workshop to advance results from this event.
